title: 111_hr3901
content: The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" enhances the administration of the first-time homebuyer tax credit. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" adds an age limitation for the tax credit on home purchases and requires documentation to prove eligibility. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" amends documentation requirements for the first-time homebuyer tax credit, including penalties for failure to attach a settlement statement to the tax return. It also restricts married individuals from acquiring a residence from the family of their spouse and treats certain errors related to the tax credit as mathematical or clerical errors. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" amends documentation requirements for the first-time homebuyer tax credit. It includes penalties for failure to attach a settlement statement to the tax return and restricts married individuals from acquiring a residence from the family of their spouse. Certain errors related to the tax credit are treated as mathematical or clerical errors. The amendments made by the "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" impose penalties for inconsistencies in claiming the tax credit, require specific forms to be attached to tax returns, and have different effective dates for various provisions. Certain tax return preparers are required to file returns electronically. Certain tax return preparers must file individual income tax returns on magnetic media if they are specified tax return preparers for the year and expect to file more than 100 returns. The term 'specified tax return preparer' refers to any tax preparer who expects to file more than 100 individual income tax returns in a calendar year. The amendment also states that the Secretary may not require electronic filing, except as provided in paragraph (3). These changes will apply to returns filed after December 31, 2010.
